raw_text: We follow the recent work of (Klementiev and Roth 2006) who addressed the problem of discovery of transliterated named entities from comparable corpora and suggested that alignment may not be necessary for transliteration

raw_text: We adopt a methodology parallel to that of [Klementiev and Roth, 2006], but we focus instead on mining parallel named entity transliteration pairs, using a well-trained linear classifier to identify transliteration pairs
clean_text: We adopt a methodology parallel to that of [Klementiev and Roth, 2006], but we focus instead on mining parallel named entity transliteration pairs, using a well-trained linear classifier to identify transliteration pairs.

raw_text: Recently, [Klementiev and Roth, 2006] outlined an approach by leveraging the availability of article aligned news corpora between English and Russian, and tools in English, for discovering transliteration pairs between the two languages, and progressively refining the discovery process
clean_text: Recently, [Klementiev and Roth, 2006] outlined an approach by leveraging the availability of article aligned news corpora between English and Russian, and tools in English, for discovering transliteration pairs between the two languages, and progressively refining the discovery process.

raw_text: As in [Klementiev and Roth, 2006] no language specific knowledge was used to refine our mining process ,making the approach broadly applicable
clean_text: As in [Klementiev and Roth, 2006] no language specific knowledge was used to refine our mining process, making the approach broadly applicable.

raw_text: In this section, we outline briefly the methodology presented in [Klementiev and Roth, 2006], and refer interested readers to the source for details
clean_text: In this section, we outline briefly the methodology presented in [Klementiev and Roth, 2006], and refer interested readers to the source for details.

raw_text: We start with comparable corpora in English and Tamil, similar in size to that used in [Klementiev and Roth, 2006], and using the English side of this corpora, first, we extract all the NEs that occur more than a given threshold parameter, FE, using a standard NER tool
clean_text: We start with comparable corpora in English and Tamil, similar in size to that used in [Klementiev and Roth, 2006], and using the English side of this corpora, first, we extract all the NEs that occur more than a given threshold parameter, FE, using a standard NER tool.

raw_text: While we adopted a methodology similar to that in [Klementiev and Roth, 2006], our focus was on mining parallel NE transliteration pairs, leveraging the availability of comparable corpora and a well-trained linear classifier to identify transliteration pairs
clean_text: While we adopted a methodology similar to that in [Klementiev and Roth, 2006], our focus was on mining parallel NE transliteration pairs, leveraging the availability of comparable corpora and a well-trained linear classifier to identify transliteration pairs.

raw_text: However, several techniques for mining name transliterations from monolingual and comparable corpora have been studied (Pasternack and Roth, 2009), (Goldwasser and Roth, 2008), (Klementiev and Roth, 2006), (Sproat et al, 2006), (Udupa et al,2009b)
clean_text: However, several techniques for mining name transliterations from monolingual and comparable corpora have been studied (Pasternack and Roth, 2009), (Goldwasser and Roth, 2008), (Klementiev and Roth, 2006), (Sproat et al, 2006), (Udupa et al, 2009b).

raw_text: Characterunigramsandbigrams were used as features to learn a discriminative transliteration model and time series similarity was combined with the transliteration similarity model (Klementiev and Roth, 2006)
clean_text: Character unigrams and bigrams were used as features to learn a discriminative transliteration model and time series similarity was combined with the transliteration similarity model (Klementiev and Roth, 2006).

raw_text: Identifying transliteration pairsis an important component in many linguistic applications which require identifying out-of-vocabulary words, such as machine translation and multilingual information retrieval (Klementiev and Roth, 2006b; Hermjakob et al, 2008)
clean_text: Identifying transliteration pairs is an important component in many linguistic applications which require identifying out-of-vocabulary words, such as machine translation and multilingual information retrieval (Klementiev and Roth, 2006b; Hermjakob et al, 2008).

raw_text: The common approach adopted is therefore to view this problem as a classification problem (Klementiev and Roth, 2006a; Tao et al, 2006) and train a discriminative classifier
clean_text: The common approach adopted is therefore to view this problem as a classification problem (Klementiev and Roth, 2006a; Tao et al, 2006) and train a discriminative classifier.

raw_text: We then use a method similar to (Klementiev and Roth, 2006a; Goldwasser and Roth, 2008) in order to discriminatively train a better weight vector for the objective function
clean_text: We then use a method similar to (Klementiev and Roth, 2006a; Goldwasser and Roth, 2008) in order to discriminatively train a better weight vector for the objective function.

raw_text: Our initial feature extraction method follows the one presented in (Klementiev and Roth, 2006a), in which the feature space consists of n-gram pairs from the two languages
clean_text: Our initial feature extraction method follows the one presented in (Klementiev and Roth, 2006a), in which the feature space consists of n-gram pairs from the two languages.
